newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: PRESS DIGEST - SOUTH AFRICA - AUGUST 5.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - SOUTH AFRICA - AUGUST 5.

text.p: These are the leading stories in the South African press on Tuesday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
BUSINESS DAY
- A dramatic increase in Spoornet's net profit, and reduced labour costs, helped Transnet cut its loss for the year to March to 170 million rand against a loss of 253 million rand the previous year.

- Dow Chemical Company has offered to buy Sentrachem for more than two billion rand in a deal which could see the U.S. multinational reinvesting substantially in South Africa following its disinvestment in 1987.

- The rand's depreciation against the dollar should not "unduly influence" monetary policy as long as it was contained to "appropriate" levels, Reserve Bank deputy governor James Gross said on Monday.

- Public servants absent for 30 days without good reason would be automatically dismissed in terms of new legislation discussed in Parliament on Monday, public service director-general Paseka Ncholo said.

- Portugal's ambassador to South Africa, Vasco Valente, had left the country after being given 48 hours to do so for allegedly leaking to the Portuguese media a letter from President Nelson Mandela to his Indonesian counterpart, the Portuguese foreign ministry said on Monday.
BUSINESS REPORT

- The U.S.-based Dow Chemical Company offered on Monday to buy Sentrachem, the local chemicals and plastics group, at 10.50 rand a share -- a 33 percent premium to the ruling share price -- in a deal worth 2.074 billion rand.

- Transnet, the state-owned transport holding company, cut its loss to 170 million rand in the year to March 31 from 253 million rand in the same period last year, Saki Macozoma, the group's managing director, said on Monday.

- The Portuguese government wanted to sell the Cahora Bassa power station in Mozambique, but the asking price was so high that nobody was interested in buying it, South African government officials told the parliamentary standing comittee on public accounts last Friday.
- The rand slipped another three cents against the dollar in early trade on Monday, but economists and traders said this was still in line with predictions.

- Autoglass, a subsidiary of the local Plate Glass and Shatterprufe Industries (PGSI) , has signed a multimillion-rand sponsorship deal with Chelsea Football Club, the English Premier League club and reigning FA Cup champions.
SAKE BEELD

- Sentrachem shareholders, who have until now faced one sad story after another, have received welcome news. It was announced on Monday that Sentrachem, which was suspended on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange, was being bought by a U.S. firm.
- Transnet's taxed income for the year to March rose 4.7 percent to 1.237 billion rand from 1.182 billion rand.
THE STAR

- Gauteng has started flexing its muscles to grab a significant slice of the estimated 30 billion rand growth in gross domestic product that is expected to be generated if Cape Town wins the bid to host the 2004 Olympic Games.

- About 2,000 people turned out in bleak weather in a field in Mannenberg at the start of a march on Monday to remember ganster Rashaad Staggie, who was shot and set alight during an anti-drugs demonstration a year ago.

- At least 2,000 defaulters (with businesses and landlords being especially targeted) face having their electricity cut off from today as Greater Johannesburg's four councils step up their campaign to recover millions in unpaid arrears.

- National coach Clive Barker opted for the tried and trusted on Monday in naming only one new face when announcing the 23-man Bafana Bafana squad to play Congo in the final World Cup Group Three soccer match at FNB stadium on August 16.

- The family of murdered Durban human rights lawyer Griffiths Mxenge will go to court "within weeks" in an attempt to overturn Monday's Truth and Reconciliation Commission decision to give his killer amnesty for the crime.
